name: smelting of copper concentrate, sulfide ore | sulfuric acid | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23341/documentation

This dataset represents the smelting of copper concentrates to produce copper anodes in India.;Background: Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals.;Modelling approach: The amounts of most exchanges are based on Classen et al. (2009). The amounts of by products from the process were calculated through a global material flow analysis of primary copper production. Electrical and thermal energy demand was based on the global smelter technology mix and estimated energy demand for each technology type (Turner & Hischier, 2020). Further information is provided in the sampling procedure, exchange comments and references.;References:;Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch.;Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

The activity starts with the delivery of copper concentrate, sulfide ore.

Ends with the production of copper anode.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Besides the values for electricity use, data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009).;Reference:;Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The energy values are representative of the smelter technology mix in India (Turner & Hischier, 2020). For the inputs from technosphere and emissions to environment, the values are based on those reported in Classen et al. (2009) for the RAS region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Based on the mix of smelter types in operation nationally in 2002; assumed here to represent the current smelter technology mix: Isasmelt–Peirce–Smith furnace, 36.4%; and Noranda–Teniente furnace, 63.6%.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
All inputs, apart from energy, and emissions to the environment are based on Classen et al. (2009). The data is based on Tables 5.8 to 5.11 in Part III. For the region-specific values, the values for the region RAS are used. For the emissions to air taken from Table 5.9, the values with limited control are used.

The values for electrical and thermal energy demand have been adjusted based on the types of smelters in operation in the geography modelled in this dataset, taken from the USGS World Copper Smelters database (Feliciano & González, 2003), and estimated energy demand of different copper smelter types (Coursol et al. 2015).

The emission of sulfur dioxide is calculated based on the shares of the types of smelters and based on the emission factors per smelter type given in Classen et al. (2009).

The amounts and composition (exchange properties) of 'copper, anode', 'copper slag' and 'blast furnace sludge' (the latter of which was used here as a proxy for flue dust) were estimated based on a global material flow analysis of copper production. For more information, please refer to the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020).

References
Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch.
Coursol, P., Mackey, P. J., Kapusta, J. P. T., & Valencia, N. C. (2015). Energy Consumption in Copper Smelting: A New Asian Horse in the Race. JOM, 67(5), 1066-1074.
Feliciano, C. S. L. & González, E. (2003). Map and Table of World Copper Smelters (online). U.S. Geological Survey. Available from: https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2003/of03-075/ (accessed 27.12.2018).
Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

exchanges.description: Based on Table 5.8 in Part III in Classen et al. (2009). The amount for the geography RAS is used. 220 kg of sulfuric acid is produced during the pre-treatment step, while 2.7 tonnes are produced during the reduction step (both values are per tonne of copper produced).

exchanges.description: Value based on Table 7 in Turner & Hischier (2020). The fossil energy input is split between natural gas and other than natural gas based on the split reported in Table 5.8 in Part III in Classen et al. (2009) for the pre-treatment and reduction steps in the region RAS.

exchanges.description: Based on Classen et al. (2009). 1.4 m3 of wastewater per tonne of copper concentrate input is assumed to be released (based on PGM operations). The exchange for unpolluted wastewater is used as the emissions to water are reported separately.

exchanges.description: Based on Classen et al. (2009). The calcination of lime results in the emission of 0.44 t CO2 per tonne of lime added.

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Represents oxygen that is supplied through compressed air (not modelled as an input, since the energy requirements are already considered in the energy inputs). It is calculated as the sum of oxygen contained in the sulfur dioxide that is converted to sulfuric acid and the oxygen contained in the sulfur dioxide emitted to air, minus the amount of pure oxygen that is supplied.

flow.name: Oxygen
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in air

exchanges.description: Based on Table 5.10 in Part III in Classen et al. (2009), 0.3 kg of PM > 2.5 and < 10um is emitted to air per tonne of copper produced.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on the smelter types provided in Table C1 in Turner & Hischier (2020) and based on the technology-specific SO2 emissions used in Classen et al. (2009). Based on Classen et al. (2009), for reverberatory furnaces, an emission of 2500 kg SO2/t Cu produced is assumed, while an emission of 150 kg SO2/t Cu produced is assumed for all other technologies. For cases where a mix of reverberatory and one or more other smelter types are reported in Table C1 in Turner & Hischier (2020), the emission factor for reverberatory furnaces is used. Additionally, based on Classen et al. (2009), an abatement of 20% is considered (value for the geography RAS).
